item.title: Kurdish Leader Calls for Iraqi Premier to Resign
item.description: Following criticism from the prime minister, the Kurdish regional government said its ministers would boycott cabinet meetings and demanded an apology.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Safin Hamed/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: Massoud Barzani, president of the Kurdish regional government, arriving for a parliamentary session in the regional capital of Erbil this month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Detain Party Critic for Role in Tiananmen Commemoration
item.description: Murong Xuecun, a prominent critic of the Communist Party whose real name is Hao Qun, was detained by the police in Beijing for his role in a small commemoration of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and MIA LI
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Journalists Warned Not to Work With Foreign Media
item.description: The Chinese government has issued a new directive that alerts local journalists not to pass on any information obtained in the course of their work to any foreign media groups or to domestic media where they are not employed.
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: Journalists working at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing. A new directive requires Chinese journalists to sign nondisclosure agreements, pledging not to transmit state secrets.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Battle Between 2 State Giants, CCTV and Bank of China, Unravels
item.description: The state broadcaster CCTV, itself mired in corruption scandals, has accused one of the countryâ€™s biggest banks of money laundering in a report that provoked both surprise and cynicism.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A Bank of China branch in Beijing. The state lender is the eighth largest in the world in terms of assets.

item.title: Letter From Europe: British Combatants of a Different Religious War
item.description: Since the so-called Arab Spring, a new militancy has arisen, beckoning Muslims in Britain and other parts of the West to join the ranks of the holy warriors.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Philip Toscano/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The memorial to the victims of the London terrorist attacks of July 7, 2005.

item.title: Death Toll Rises in Gaza, as Hamas Hits Deeper in Israel
item.description: At least 67 Palestinians were said to have died in Israeli airstrikes in Gaza, while rocket fire from the Palestinian coastal enclave reached ever-broader swaths of Israel. An Israeli military spokesman said 20,000 reserve troops had been called up.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM
item.media:description: Israeli troops outside the Gaza Strip on Thursday. A spokesman for the Israeli military said the current focus of the ground forces was to uncover tunnels in Gaza used by militants for attacks.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Sarkozyâ€™s Reckless Political Encore
item.description: To fend off corruption charges, he is borrowing from the populist rightâ€™s playbook.
item.dc:creator: By ARTHUR GOLDHAMMER

item.title: Nuclear Material Seized by Rebels in Iraq Is â€˜Low-Grade,â€™ U.N. Says
item.description: The United Nations atomic energy agency said the material, taken by Sunni insurgents, does not present a significant security threat.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Latin Americaâ€™s Talent for Tolerance
item.description: Today, violent and fanatic racism is the exception and not the rule in our part of the world.
item.dc:creator: By ENRIQUE KRAUZE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Li Chengpengâ€™s Social Media and Blog Accounts Suspended
item.description: The commentatorâ€™s Sina Weibo and Tencent Weibo microblog and blog accounts disappeared Monday evening in what appears to be part of Chinaâ€™s continuing effort to muzzle outspoken voices online.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN

item.title: Brazilians Grumble and Take Stock After Crushing World Cup Loss
item.description: While the hope was to blot out the bad memory of the last time the country hosted the World Cup, the outcome was if anything worse. But in a more mature Brazil, people are asking whether it will matter as much.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: U.S. Counterterrorism Chief to Step Down
item.description: Matthew G. Olsen has been director of the National Counterterrorism Center as threats from Al Qaeda shifted from Pakistan to Syria, Iraq and Yemen.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: New-Design Rocket Is Launched
item.description: Russia launched the Angara rocket, its first new design of space rocket since the Soviet era, from the northern military space port of Plesetsk.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Counterterrorism Chief Stepping Down
item.description: Matthew G. Olsen, the director of the National Counterterrorism Center, is resigning after three years.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing: Switzerland: Former Banker Is Charged
item.description: A Swiss prosecutor brought charges on Wednesday against Rudolf Elmer, a former banker in the Cayman Islands with the Swiss bank Julius Baer.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Egypt Silent as Neighbors Wage Battles
item.description: Egyptians appear to be barely lifting a finger as the Gaza death toll mounts, leaving the Palestinians and the Israelis without a go-between.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Fleeing Gangs, Children Head to U.S. Border
item.description: An increase in gang-related killings of children is a key factor driving the surge of migration of young Central Americans to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clothes were laid out in remembrance of Kenneth Castellanos, 7, who was tortured and killed in his Honduran neighborhood.

item.title: World Cup 2014: Five German Kicks Felt in Brazilian Guts Everywhere
item.description: Brazilian fans began Tuesday's semifinal against Germany with high hopes, but Brazil was 5-0 down within 29 minutes, its World Cup dreams devastated.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN

item.title: France Aims to Curb Potential Jihadis From Leaving Country
item.description: Officials fear the threat posed by Western proponents of Islamic terrorism returning from training or combat in Syria.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Budget Is Key Test for Indiaâ€™s New Government
item.description: The clear mandate given to the government offers both domestic and foreign investors reason to hope for tough calls to rescue the floundering economy.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: Obama Administration Defends Israeli Airstrikes but Cautions Against Ground War
item.description: In a telephone call to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Secretary of State John Kerry said the United States would try to help Israel fulfill its goal of stopping Hamasâ€™s rocket fire without a ground assault.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Polls Slow Japanâ€™s Plan to Revise Constitution
item.description: Shinzo Abe, the prime minister of Japan, appears to have slowed efforts to expand the role of the military after polls showed a significant drop in his administrationâ€™s approval rating.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MAKIKO INOUE and NEIL GOUGH

item.title: Patchwork Makeup of Rebels Fighting Ukraine Makes Peace Talks Elusive
item.description: One Russian separatist leader is said to be trying to unite the mishmash of militias into a single professional fighting force, while the national military prepares to attempt to retake the rebel stronghold of Donetsk.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Chinese Hackers Pursue Key Data on U.S. Workers
item.description: It is not yet clear how far the hackers penetrated the systems of the Office of Personnel Management, in which applicants for security clearances list their personal information.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT, DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Longyearbyen Journal: A Harsh Climate Calls for Banishment of the Needy
item.description: While the rest of Norway has generous welfare programs, in the frigid territory of Svalbard, unemployment and homelessness are illegal, which officials say reduces crime.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Kyrre Lien for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Norwegian town of Longyearbyen in Svalbard prides itself on its crime-free streets. Residents, however, are required to carry weapons to fend off polar bears.
